input:
Comment: Z,

Sec 171-36 (b)(1) exists in current law.  I asked for it to be removed early in session when I was questioning a Chair,  given the ambiguity it carries.  He advised later that the DAG prefers it stay in.  The subsection has (apparently) never been used, and if you think it might be used for something big someday, e.g. TMT, well it hasn't been used so far.  So perhaps it's viewed as some kind of "nuclear option".  I really don't know.

Please,  I am not disseminating "misinformation".  If I state an opinion, I'll back it up with why I arrived at that conclusion.  If I advise someone they've misunderstood a concept I point out the inconsistency, I don't accuse them of ignorance or evil.    I'm very familiar with this bill, know it's intent, and am appalled at the lack of in depth analysis, or concern for consequences, displayed by those commenting.  This is a serious issue, and the criticisms of this bill are frequently founded on mischaracterizations or misunderstandings.

input:
Comment: Bail is a right under both Alaska and federal constitutions. A person charged with an offense is not legally guilty of it, no matter what the police say.  Curious, how some people burn incense before a constitutional right they like and ignore the ones they don't like.

Granted, the court has discretion in setting the amount of bail, provided it is not "excessive."  There are different interpretations of that word.  In some minds it means "excessive compared to the bail usually set for similar charges."  In others, it means "excessive compared to the defendant's resources."  Usually, the court considers both.

People also don't realize that there is a distinction between cash bail and "corporate" bail.  The latter means a bail bondsman puts up a bond for you (for which he will mulct you dearly).  Usually, the defendant in felony cases is required to post at least 10% of his total bail amount in cash.  The article doesn't say whether the $2,500 was the whole bail, or only the cash part.

input:
Comment: Nice job BB!

Taking your analysis a little further, if enough Sanders supporters follow folks like the frequent poster here over the cliff, Sanders' "ideals" will be consigned to the ash-can of history. How can any sensible person believe that a Trump presidency would do anything other than place enormous power in a cabal of fascists?

I'm from the south, and I know a number of folks who have worked with Hillary, and she's held in the highest regard for her life's work. As another post pointed out, she's been the target of a relentless false narrative. Has she made mistakes? Of course. And some of them were big ones.

But she's been in the middle of the toughest decisions one can imagine and had to fight election campaigns with brutal adversaries. Sanders has never been tested by fire. And Trump is a maniacal clown, except as president of the most powerful country in the world, not so funny.

Let's hope smart folks who stood with Clinton in the primaries work hard for her election.

instruction: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: identity-attack and non-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything rude or disrespectful about someone's identity, including appearance, race, gender, and sexual orientation.
input: Comment: Putin said last week that "the Americans have a mental disease and have lost their minds."  He is right.  That was before today where that Bernie Sanders supporter went nuts. It will likely get worse.
